wikipedia_page.main: William James Baker MM (1882 – 22 October 1916) was an English professional footballer who made 202 appearances as a wing half in the Southern League and FA Cup for Plymouth Argyle between 1909 and 1915. He also played in the United States and South Africa.

link_mentions.page: Association football during World War I
response: Many football players, both amateur and professional, lost their lives. Larrett Roebuck was the first player from the English league to die, on 18 October 1914. Scottish side Heart of Midlothian lost seven players. Another Scottish side, Brechin City, lost six players. English team Bradford City, for example, lost nine players – first-team players Bob Torrance, Jimmy Speirs, Evelyn Lintott, James Conlin, James Comrie, Gerald Kirk, and reserve players George Draycott, Ernest Goodwin, and Harry Potter. William Baker, a member of the Plymouth Argyle team that won the Southern League in 1913, was killed in Serre during the Battle of the Somme. The website created by the Professional Footballers' Association, 'Football and the First World War' currently lists 296 players who were killed in the war. Football and the First World War, page 'Footballers Killed in the First World War'.
